Interoception, a concept first introduced over 100 years ago 5, defines a fundamental 40 biological process whereby the nervous system senses and responds to the inner state of the body 41 including that of internal organs 6. Recent work has begun to unravel the neural mechanisms for 42 interoception in many tissues, including the larynx, heart, intestine, and bladder 7-11. However, 43 knowledge remains limited on complete multi-synaptic circuits that sense signals from organs, 44 integrate them in the nervous system, and respond to them through modulation of organ function. 45 The lung, given its large surface area, rich nerve innervation and direct exposure to aerosol 46 environment, is a prominent source of interoceptive signals 12-15. In lung, airway constriction, 47 triggered by exposure to irritants including allergen, is a normal protective physiologic response. 48 It is driven by contraction of smooth muscles that wrap around the airways 16. Following chronic 49 exposure, allergen would trigger exacerbated airway constriction, also termed airway 50 hyperreactivity. The resulting restricted airflow is a primary asthma morbidity and a major cause 51 of asthma-associated deaths. 52 It has been shown that in repeated allergen-challenged mice but not in naïve mice, vagotomy 53 abolished airway hyperreactivity as assayed in the presence of methacholine, a synthetic 54 acetylcholine analogue, suggesting dependence of the hyperreactivity on vagal reflex 2. 55 Similarly, ablation or repression of Trpv1+ or Nav1.8+ vagal afferent neurons led to reduced 56 airway hyperreactivity in allergen-challenged mice, but not methacholine-induced acute 57 constriction in naïve mice 3,4. In the context of repeated allergen-induced airway hyperreactivity, 58 the identity of the nodes downstream of vagal afferent neurons, their molecular signatures, and 59 the nature of neurotransmitters and signals remain poorly defined. 60 A key knowledge gap is the brainstem neurons important for transmitting the chronic 61 allergen signal. Mapping data from us and others show that lung-innervating vagal sensory 62 neurons project exclusively to the nucleus of the solitary tract (nTS) region of the brainstem 63 8,13,15,17. Aside from lung, nTS integrates sensory inputs from many organs including the heart, 64 gut and intestine 8,9,14,18,19. As a key signal relay center, neurons in the nTS project to higher 65 order brain nuclei, as well as effector areas in the brainstem, including the dorsal motor nucleus 66 of the vagus nerve (DMV) and nucleus ambiguous (NA) 20-22. Systematic analyses of the 67 neuronal diversity of the nTS and their downstream nodes are critical for interrogating functional 68 heterogeneity and specificity. 69 In this study, we dissect the mechanism of how normal lungs react to repeated allergen 70 exposures, a disease-relevant adaptive response that is distinct from acute airway constriction. In 71 wild-type mice, we show that repeated, but not single, allergen challenges led to localized 72 activation of nTS neurons. This activation is reduced in either mast cell mutants, after treatment 73 with interleukin 4 (IL-4) neutralizing antibody, or upon vagotomy. Genetic ablation of activated 74 nTS neurons blunted allergen-induced airway hyperreactivity, but not goblet cell metaplasia or 75 type 2 immune cell recruitment. Using single-nucleus RNA sequencing (snRNA-seq), we 76 identified 13 distinct neuron types in the nTS. Using this dataset, we identified a single Dbh+ 77 sub-population that is enriched for allergen-activated neurons. Ablating or disrupting the 78 function of Dbh+ nTS neurons blunted airway hyperreactivity, while activating them in place of 79 allergen exposure promoted hyperreactivity in sensitized airways. On the descending efferent 80 side, Dbh+ nTS neurons project to parasympathetic neurons in the NA region of the brainstem. 81 Chemogenetic inactivation of Chat+ neurons in the NA, but not the DMV, attenuated airway 82 hyperreactivity, while activation of NA neurons in place of allergen exposure promoted 83 hyperreactivity in sensitized airways. Blocking norepinephrine receptors in the NA blunted 84 allergen-induced airway hyperreactivity. Instead of projecting directly to lung, NA neurons 85 project to postganglionic neurons in the trachea and extrapulmonary bronchi, which in turn target 86 airway smooth muscles. Taken together, these in vivo data delineate a complete interoception 87
neural circuit in the normal lung that is conditioned by repeated allergen exposures, and is 88 composed of nodes in the brainstem that are both necessary and sufficient for allergen-induced 89 airway hyperreactivity, mimicking exacerbated airway constriction in asthma. 90 91 nTS neurons were activated upon repeated, but not single, inhaled allergen challenges 92
To investigate neurons involved in allergen response, we used a mouse model of asthma with 93 chronic intranasal instillation of house dust mites (HDM), a known trigger for asthmatic 94 responses in human and rodents 23. We employed a well-established regimen, with multiple 95 doses of allergen administrations to lung (Fig. 1a) 24,25. This triggered the expected asthmatic 96 responses including exacerbated airway smooth muscle constriction, also termed hyperreactivity, 97 goblet cell metaplasia and type 2 immune cell infiltration (Fig. 1q, r, Extended Data Fig. 1a, 6d-98 f). Extending beyond previous findings indicating that allergen acts through vagal neurons 3,4,26, 99 we addressed if allergen administered to lung could trigger brainstem neuron activation. 100 Immunostaining for immediate early factor FOS, a neuronal activation marker, two hours after 101 each of the challenges in serial sections of the whole brainstem revealed an increase of FOS+ 102 cells in HDM-treated mice compared to saline-treated control mice (Fig. 1b, c, Extended Data 103 Fig. 1b-v). Increased FOS+ cells were enriched in the dorsomedial part of the nTS region 104 between Bregma -7.20 mm and Bregma -8.08 mm (Extended Data Fig. 1b-u) in comparison to 105 other regions such as the adjoining area postrema (AP), DMV and hypoglossal nucleus (12N) 106 (Extended Data Fig. 2a, b). This enrichment in the nTS is consistent with the findings that lung 107 innervating sensory nerves project specifically to the same dorsomedial part of the nTS at these 108 Bregma regions 8,13,15,17. The increase is found to be statistically significant only after the 4th 109 HDM challenge, but not after the previous three doses (Extended Data Fig. 3a-i), further 110 corroborated by Fos transcript signal (Extended Data Fig. 4a, b). These findings suggest that 111 there is conditioning of nTS neurons by repeated, but not single-dose administration of allergen. 112 It is reported that mast cells are required for the development of allergen-induced airway 113 constriction 27-29. Using the same mast cell deficient c-Kitw-sh/w-sh mice, we found a statistically 114 significant decrease of FOS+ neurons in the nTS following HDM challenge compared to 115 heterozygous c-Kitw-sh/+ controls (Fig. 1d, e). These data suggest that signals relayed through 116 mast cells are an important contributor to allergen-induced nTS activation. 117 Mast cells are among immune cells that produce type 2 immune signals, including interleukin 118 4 (IL-4), which are critical for allergen-induced airway hyperreactivity 30,31. It is reported that 119 neutralization of IL-4 using antibodies can abrogate allergen-induced airway hyperreactivity 30. 120 Using the same IL-4 neutralizing antibody and regimen, we found that administration of anti-IL-121 4, but not isotype control antibody significantly decreased the number of FOS+ neurons in the 122 nTS (Fig. 1f-h). 123 To determine if vagal nerves are essential for allergen activation of nTS, we performed 124 unilateral vagotomy before allergen administration. This led to a statistically significant decrease 125 of FOS+ neurons on the ipsilateral operated side compared to the contralateral side following 126 HDM challenge (Fig. 1i, j), suggesting that vagal nerves are required for transmitting allergen 127 signals to the nTS. 128 To further quantify cumulative allergen-induced activation and also test a tool to manipulate 129 these neurons, we crossed Fos2A-iCreER (TRAP2) mice to Rosa-lxl-tdTomato (Ai14) mice to label 130 activated neurons with tdTomato. Following 4-OH tamoxifen injection after each of the HDM 131 challenge or saline administration (2nd, 3rd and 4th doses, Fig. 1k), we cleared the whole brain and 132 brainstem using CLARITY 32. We found a statistically significant increase of activated 133 tdTomato+ neurons in the nTS of HDM-treated mice compared to saline-treated controls (Fig. 1l, 134
m). This was further confirmed through serial sectioning and quantification (Extended Data Fig. 135 5a-c). These findings paved the way for manipulating these allergen-activated nTS neurons. 136
137 Ablation of allergen-activated nTS neurons blunted airway hyperreactivity 138 To determine if activation of nTS neurons plays a role in allergen-induced responses, we 139 crossed Fos2A-iCreER; Rosa-lxl-tdTomato (TRAP2; Ai14) mice to Rosa-lxl-DTR mice to express 140 diphtheria toxin receptor (DTR) in allergen-activated neurons (TRAP2; Ai14; DTR, Fig. 1n). 141 Following bilateral injection of diphtheria toxin (DTX) into nTS, we confirmed a decrease of 142 allergen-activated neurons in the nTS (Fig. 1o, p). 143 To determine if targeted nTS neuron ablation affects airway hyperreactivity, we utilized a 144 well-established assay that is tailored to test this exacerbated adaptive physiological response as 145 a result of repeated allergen challenges 1,33. Following the last dose of HDM or saline 146 administration, increasing doses of methacholine, a synthetic analogue of acetylcholine, was 147 intratracheally administered into the airway to mimic what occurs in asthma patients, namely 148 how acute triggers elicit chronically heightened airway exacerbation, the so-called “asthma 149 attack”. Aside from directly acting on airway smooth muscles to trigger contraction, 150 methacholine also signals to vagal afferent fibers to activate them which enhance smooth muscle 151 constriction 2-4,34. In rodents, lung mechanics including airway hyperreactivity are commonly 152 assayed using the flexiVent system. 153 Using this assay, in wild-type mice, as expected, we found that multiple doses of HDM 154 sensitization and challenge led to further increase of flexiVent measurement of respiratory 155 system resistance (Rrs) and elastance (Ers) compared to the saline control group, demonstrating 156 allergen-induced airway hyperreactivity (Fig. 1q, r, N=5 for Saline, N=6 for HDM). As this 157 hyperreactivity is abrogated by vagotomy 2, the differential airway constriction between the 158 HDM and saline groups is primarily due to methacholine-activated vagal reflex rather than its 159 direct effect on airway smooth muscles. Thus, by comparing the extent of airway constriction 160 triggered by the same concentration of methacholine, we used the differences between 161 experimental groups and corresponding controls as a measure of the impact of the chronically 162 adaptive vagal circuit. 163 In the DTR-DTX experimental group, DTX ablation of allergen-activated nTS neurons led to 164 blunted airway hyperreactivity compared to vehicle-injected group (Fig. 1s, t, N=4 for vehicle 165 injection control, N=7 for DTX injection), suggesting that allergen-activated nTS neurons are 166 part of the circuit conditioned by HDM to control airway hyperreactivity. In contrast, there was 167 no change in HDM-induced goblet cell metaplasia, type 2 immune cell recruitment or expression 168 of key type 2 cytokine genes Il4, Il5 and Il13 (Extended Data Fig. 6a-i). These data together 169 suggest that while allergen-activated nTS neurons do not substantially modulate goblet 170 metaplasia or type 2 immune recruitment, they are critical for amplifying allergen-induced 171 airway hyperreactivity. 172
173 Single nucleus transcriptomic signatures of the nTS allow dissection of diversity and 174 selectivity 175 The nTS is known to receive diverse signals from many organs, including lung, heart, gut, 176 intestine, etc 8,9,14,18,19. To identify which specific subset of the nTS neurons were activated by 177 allergen response in lung, we started with defining the overall molecular diversity of the nTS 178 through single-nucleus RNA sequencing (snRNA-seq) using flash frozen tissues. This method 179 was chosen over single-cell RNA sequencing to avoid tissue digestion, cell dissociation and 180 sorting which reduces neuronal viability and can also artificially induce cellular stress signatures 181 35. Using anatomical landmarks to minimize incorporation of the adjacent AP and DMV regions, 182
we dissected the whole nTS region from adult wild-type mice (Fig. 2a). Transcriptome data from 183 12,966 nTS nuclei were obtained using 10x Genomics technology. Unsupervised clustering 184 analysis revealed 8148 neurons and 4818 glial cells. Focusing on neurons, we further purified 185 nTS neurons in silico by excluding AP and DMV neurons as identified by their profiles from two 186 recently published snRNA-seq datasets of these regions 36,37. The remaining nTS neurons 187 segregated into 13 clusters as shown in uniform manifold approximation and projection (UMAP) 188 plots (Fig. 2b), a comparable number to a recent published nTS single cell-RNAseq dataset 38. 189 All 13 neuronal clusters express pan-neuronal markers Rbfox3 and Snap25 (Fig. 2c, d), with little 190 expression of glial marker genes (GFAP, Olig1, Aqp4 or Tmem119, Extended Data Fig. 7a-d). 191 Five neuronal clusters (Clusters 1, 2, 5, 9,12) are Scl17a6+ glutamatergic excitatory neurons, 192 while the remaining eight clusters (Clusters 3, 4, 6, 7, 8, 10, 11,13) are Slc32a1+ GABAergic 193 inhibitory neurons (Fig. 2e, f). Individual neuronal populations were clearly distinguished by a 194 set of marker genes (Fig. 2g). We further validated the expressions of marker genes using UMAP 195 plots and either our own RNAscope in situ hybridization assay (for excitatory clusters, Fig. 2h-q) 196 or data from the Allen Brain Atlas (for inhibitory clusters, Extended Data Fig. 7e-l). A 197 comprehensive analysis of genes encoding neurotransmitter/neuropeptide receptors, 198 neurotransmitter synthesis/secretion machineries, neuropeptides and hormones revealed the 199 molecular capabilities of each neuronal population in receiving and transmitting signals 200 (Extended Data Fig. 7m-o). 201
202 Dbh+ neurons in the nTS were preferentially activated upon allergen challenge 203 To determine the molecular signature of allergen-activated nTS neurons, we compared nTS 204 snRNA-seq signatures of wild-type mice 1.5 hours after the 4th saline or 4th HDM challenge. 205 Compared to naïve nTS, the same 13 neuron subtypes were detected in saline- and HDM-206 challenged nTS (Fig. 3a, Extended Data Fig. 8a). Among the five clusters (Clusters 1, 6, 7, 10 207 and 12) that show Log2 average expression levels of Fos above 0, Cluster 1 is the only excitatory 208 cluster that showed an increase of the percentage of Fos+ neurons (Fig. 3b, Extended Data Fig. 209 8b). Hence, we focused on Cluster 1 to determine its role in allergen-induced responses. 210 To validate that Cluster 1 neurons were activated upon HDM challenge, we performed 211 double in situ hybridization with Fos and Cluster 1 marker gene Dbh (Fig. 3c). By Dbh 212 RNAscope in situ hybridization on serial sections, we found that within nTS, Dbh expression is 213 consistently detected between Bregma -6.96 mm and Bregma -8.08 mm, encompassing the 214 regions where allergen-induced Fos+ cells were enriched (Extended Data Fig. 1b-u, Extended 215 Data Fig. 9a). On individual sections, we observed a substantial overlap between Dbh and Fos, 216 where 59.11% Dbh+ neurons were Fos+, and 38.18% Fos+ neurons were Dbh+ (Fig. 3d, N=12 217 sections). To better assay the spectrum of allergen-activated neurons, we also screened a number 218 of additional known nTS neuronal markers 38-40, including Cnr1, Th and Cck. We found that after 219 HDM challenge, there were some Fos overlap with Cnr1 and Th, but not Cck (Extended Data 220
Fig. 10a-c). Among Fos+ neurons, the Dbh+ neurons appear more enriched compared to Cnr1+ or 221 Th+ neurons. 222 To further confirm that Dbh+ neurons were activated, and to validate a driver line to 223 manipulate these neurons, we crossed transgenic Dbh-cre mice to Rosa-lxl-tdTomato (Ai14) 224
mice. In Dbh-cre; Ai14 mice, double in situ hybridization of Dbh and tdTomato showed >95% 225 overlap of signals, confirming specificity of cre expression (Extended Data Fig. 11a, b, N=6 226 sections). After HDM administrations in Dbh-cre; Ai14 mice, we observed a substantial overlap 227 between tdTomato+ and FOS+ neurons in the nTS (41.99% tdTomato+ neurons were Fos+, and 228 57.59% Fos+ neurons were tdTomato+), further confirming that Dbh+ neurons were activated 229 upon allergen challenges to lung (Fig. 3e, f, N=8 sections). 230
Ablation or inactivation of Dbh+ neurons in the nTS blunted airway hyperreactivity 231 To determine if Dbh+ nTS neurons are necessary for mediating allergen response, we 232 employed three approaches. First, we performed chemical ablation by injecting anti-DBH 233 antibody conjugated to the toxin Saporin (SAP). DBH-SAP was previously validated to 234 specifically ablate DBH+ neurons with no effects on neighboring neurons 41. We injected anti-235 DBH-SAP stereotactically into both sides of the nTS of wild-type mice before allergen challenge 236 (Fig. 4a). Compared to scrambled peptide-conjugated SAP (blank-SAP) control, anti-DBH-SAP 237 group showed a clear reduction of DBH+ neurons after injection, confirming ablation efficiency 238 (Fig. 4b). There is little change in the size of other excitatory nTS neuronal subsets as labeled by 239 their specific markers, including Gli3 (Cluster 2), Sncg (Cluster 5), Slc17a7 (Cluster 9) or Mafa 240 (Cluster 12), confirming ablation specificity (Extended Data Fig. 12a-f). Following HDM 241 treatment, the anti-DBH-SAP injected group showed reduced FOS+ cells compared to blank-SAP 242 control (Extended Data Fig. 13a-c). As a baseline control, in flexiVent assays, DBH+ neuron 243 ablation had no effect on methacholine responses in naïve mice not exposed to HDM (Extended 244 Data Fig. 13d-e, N=3 for blank-SAP+Saline, N=4 for anti-DBH-SAP+Saline). In contrast, 245 following HDM challenge, the anti-DBH-SAP treated group showed statistically significant 246 blunted airway hyperreactivity compared to the blank-SAP control group (Fig. 4c, d, N=4 for 247 blank-SAP+HDM, N=9 for anti-DBH-SAP+HDM). 248 Second, we performed genetic ablation by crossing Dbh-cre mice to Rosa-lxl-DTR mice 249 (Dbh-cre; DTR) and then injected DTX bilaterally into nTS (Fig. 4e). This led to efficient loss of 250 Dbh+ neurons in the nTS (Fig. 4f). Following this targeted genetic ablation, we carried out HDM 251 challenge and found that allergen-induced airway hyperreactivity was blunted in the DTX group 252 compared to vehicle-injected control group (Fig. 4g, h, N=10 for vehicle+HDM, N=10 for 253 DTX+HDM). 254 Third, we performed chemogenetic inactivation using Designer Receptors 255 Exclusively Activated by Designer Drugs (DREADD) system. We injected AAV-flex-256 hM4D(Gi)-mCherry bilaterally into nTS of Dbh-cre mice, eliciting efficient and specific 257 expression in the nTS, but not nearby regions such as AP (Fig. 4i, Extended Data Fig. 16a, b). 258 Following robust expression, we started the HDM regimen and administered Clozapine-N-Oxide 259 (CNO) to activate hM4D(Gi) before the 2nd to the 4th HDM, sparing the first HDM to allow for 260 sensitization of the immune system which is required for subsequent activation of the nervous 261 system 3. We found that the CNO group showed blunted airway hyperreactivity response 262 compared to vehicle group (Fig. 4j, k, N=5 for HDM+vehicle, N=9 for HDM+CNO). Taking 263 together, data from chemical ablation, genetic ablation and chemogenetic inactivation 264 demonstrate that Dbh+ nTS neurons constitute an essential node of the circuit critical for 265 allergen-induced airway hyperreactivity. 266
267 Activation of Dbh+ neurons in the nTS induced airway hyperreactivity 268 To address if Dbh+ neurons in the nTS are sufficient for mediating allergen response, we 269 used DREADD targeted activation. We injected AAV-DIO-hM3D(Gq)-mCherry into bilateral 270 nTS of Dbh-cre mice, eliciting efficient and specific expression in the nTS (Fig. 4l, Extended 271 Data Fig. 17a). Following this robust expression, we started the HDM regimen and administrated 272 CNO in place of the 4th HDM challenge while all groups received the 1st to the 3rd doses of 273 HDM. The flexiVent data showed that while not to the full extent as HDM, CNO activation of 274 Dbh+ neurons in place of the 4th dose was sufficient to induce increased airway hyperreactivity 275 compared to saline control (Fig. 4m, n, N=5 for 4th HDM, N=11 for 4th CNO, N=8 for 4th 276 Vehicle). In contrast, in naïve mice not exposed to HDM, CNO activation (the 4th dose) of Dbh+ 277 neurons had no effect (Extended Data Fig. 17b-d, N=3 for 4th Saline+vehicle, N=5 for 4th 278
Saline+CNO). Taking both loss- and gain-of-function data together, these findings suggest that 279 the activity of Dbh+ neurons in the nTS is both necessary and sufficient for mediating allergen-280 induced airway hyperreactivity. 281 In none of the three loss-of-function experiments, nor the chemogenetic gain-of-function 282 experiment did we observe any changes in HDM-induced goblet cell metaplasia, increased 283 immune cell infiltration or expression of Il4, Il5 and Il13 (Extended Data Fig. 14a-f, 15a-f, 16c-i, 284 18a-h). These findings together confirm findings from TRAP2; Ai14; DTR mice (Extended Data 285 Fig. 6a-i). We also assayed for possible effects on other aspects of lung function. Following 286 either HDM challenge or CNO-activation, compared to saline controls, we found no significant 287 difference in minute ventilation, respiratory frequency, tidal volume, or metabolic rate, as 288 measured by plethysmography (Extended Data Fig. 19a-g). This is consistent with previous 289 report that HDM challenge in mice did not change respiratory parameters 42. These results 290 indicate that CNO activation of Dbh+ nTS neurons induced airway hyperreactivity in sensitized 291 airways without affecting respiration. 292
293 Parasympathetic neurons in the NA are downstream of Dbh+ nTS and upstream of airway-294 innervating postganglionic neurons 295 To map the downstream targets of Dbh+ nTS neurons and their role in mediating allergen-296 induced airway hyperreactivity, we injected AAV-flex-tdTomato to the nTS of Dbh-cre mice 297 (Fig. 5a). No fiber was detected in either the trachea or the lung, indicating that Dbh+ nTS 298 neurons do not innervate the airway directly. 387 Discussion 388 In this study, our findings delineate a full neural circuit where chronic allergen challenges to 389 lung are transmitted through immune cells such as IL-4 producing immune cells and ascending 390 vagal afferents to a Dbh+ subset of the nTS central integrator, which acts through descending 391 efferent neurons (Adra1a+/Adra1b+) in the NA before projecting back to postganglionic neurons 392 innervating the airway to control airway hyperreactivity (Fig. 6r). This is a circuit identified in 393 wild-type mice following repeated conditioning by allergen, suggesting the presence of an 394 intrinsic molecular and cellular response machinery. Recurring irritation is a common cause of 395 chronic diseases and repeated allergen exposure is central to asthma pathogenesis. Our findings 396 reveal a disease-relevant circuit with players from the immune system, the nervous system and 397 functional cells of the organ. 398 We found that only repeated, but not single, allergen challenges led to a statistically 399 significant increase in activated nTS neurons. This exemplifies a cardinal feature of chronic 400 conditioning, a behavior that is distinct from mechanisms that drive acute airway constriction 401 2,52,53. These results provide an example of experience-driven neural plasticity in peripheral 402 interoceptive circuits, which are analogous to features classically showcased by central nervous 403 system neurons in learning and memory. 404 While methacholine can induce acute airway constriction in both groups, repeated allergen 405 challenge led to exacerbated response above the level in naïve animals. Our data demonstrate 406 that this elevated airway resistance was blunted by ablation or chemogenetic inactivation of 407 Dbh+ nTS neurons, demonstrating for the first time the critical role of the nTS neurons in this 408 response. Despite differences, airway hyperreactivity and acute airway constriction may share 409 overlapping nodes. Activation of nervous system in naïve animals, by either electrical 410 stimulation of vagal C-fiber, chemical induction of MrgprC11+ vagal neurons, or optogenetic 411 stimulation of thoracic cholinergic nerves, induced acute airway constriction in the absence of 412 exogenous methacholine 26,52,53. These findings suggest that repeated allergen exposures may 413 hijack these existing nodes, condition them through molecular changes or anatomical 414 remodeling, to elevate airway constriction above the threshold level of acute response, 415 mimicking asthma. Our results further define the identity of the brainstem neurons that connect 416 the afferent and efferent nodes to control airway constriction. 417 While the combined connectivity is necessary and sufficient for allergen-induced 418 hyperactivity, individual nodes of this allergen circuit may also function in other physiological or 419 pathological settings. For example, Dbh-expressing nTS neurons were implicated in appetite 420 control by projecting to the lateral parabrachial nucleus or in the arcuate nucleus of the 421 hypothalamus 54-56. Dissecting the anatomical connectivity and the pairing of 422
neurotransmitter/neuropeptide to their receptors are key to unraveling the different roles of the 423 same neuron type in distinct circuits. Towards this goal, our snRNA-seq datasets of the nTS and 424 NA provide the basis for dissecting molecular connectivity and specificity. In the context of the 425 allergen circuit, these two datasets, together with existing lung and vagal neuron single cell 426 datasets, and the knowledge that acetylcholine is the likely neurotransmitter from NA to airway 427 smooth muscle cells, complete the connectome of the allergen circuit (Extended Data Fig. 23a-c) 428 7,8,47,48. Two recent studies delineated diverse functions of NA neurons in targeting the 429 esophagus, the heart and/or the lung 45,46. It is likely that the cardiopulmonary subset of the NA 430 neurons is responsible for mediating allergen response. 431 The molecular signatures of the allergen hyperreactivity circuit enables a novel dimension for 432 modulating airway tone in asthma. Neuromodulation could bypass the systemic side effects of 433 current asthma treatments that relay on administration of steroids and biologics. This adaptive 434 circuit showcases the importance of neuroimmune control of organ function. Beyond the lung, 435 mapping how organs act through their peripheral and central nerve connections to receive, 436 process and respond to chronic inputs will open a new dimension in the modulation of disease-437 relevant interoceptive activities. 438 439
